skill.name: string-database
skill.description: Query STRING API for protein-protein interactions (59M proteins, 20B interactions). Network analysis, GO/KEGG enrichment, interaction discovery, 5000+ species, for systems biology.
skill.summary: Query STRING API for protein-protein interactions (59M proteins, 20B interactions). Network analysis...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate bioinformatics tool for querying the STRING database (a well-known, ELIXIR-designated biodata resource). The Python helper functions make documented API calls to string-db.org for protein interaction data. No dangerous patterns, credential theft, or data exfiltration detected. Only minimal network access to a single trusted endpoint.

content.user_title: Query protein interactions with STRING database
content.value_statement: Systems biologists need protein-protein interaction data to understand gene function and pathways. This skill provides Python functions to query the STRING database API for interaction networks, functional enrichment, and homology data across 5000 species.
actual_capabilities: Map gene names and protein identifiers to STRING database IDs
Retrieve protein-protein interaction networks with confidence scores
Generate network visualization images in PNG format
Find interaction partners and hub proteins
Perform functional enrichment analysis (GO, KEGG, Pfam, InterPro)
Test if proteins form significantly connected functional modules
limitations: Requires internet access to query the STRING API endpoint
Rate limited to approximately 1 request per second
Does not store local copies of database; queries must be re-run for fresh data
Network images are returned as binary PNG data that must be saved explicitly

use_cases.title: Pathway analysis
use_cases.description: Identify enriched GO terms and KEGG pathways in a list of proteins from proteomics experiments

use_cases.title: Interaction discovery
use_cases.description: Find all known interaction partners for a protein of interest and visualize the network

use_cases.title: Cross-species comparison
use_cases.description: Compare protein interaction networks across human, mouse, and model organisms

prompt_templates.title: Basic lookup
prompt_templates.prompt: Use string_network_image to show the interaction network for {protein_name} in human

prompt_templates.title: Enrichment analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Use string_enrichment to find GO terms and KEGG pathways enriched in {protein_list}

prompt_templates.title: Partner discovery
prompt_templates.prompt: Use string_interaction_partners to find top {n} high-confidence interactors of {protein}

prompt_templates.title: Complete workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Map these gene names to STRING IDs, get their interaction network at 700 confidence, test for PPI enrichment, and generate a network visualization

output_examples.input: Get TP53 interaction network and functional enrichment
output: TP53 interacts with 150+ proteins including MDM2, ATM, CHEK2, BRCA1, and ATR
Enriched pathways: p53 signaling pathway (FDR 1.2e-45), DNA repair (FDR 3.4e-38), apoptosis (FDR 8.1e-25)
PPI enrichment p-value < 0.001: TP53 network is significantly more connected than random
Network visualization shows evidence-colored edges: experimental (purple), database (blue), text-mining (green)

best_practices: Map gene names to STRING IDs first for faster and more reliable queries
Use confidence thresholds appropriate for your analysis (400 for discovery, 700 for validation)
Always specify species using NCBI taxon IDs for accurate results
Wait 1 second between API calls to respect rate limits
anti_patterns: Using gene names without mapping them to STRING IDs first
Setting required_score too low (150) which includes many false positive interactions
Querying large protein lists (>50) without batching or splitting requests
Forgetting to save network images since they are binary data returned as bytes

faq.question: Which species are supported?
faq.answer: STRING covers 5000+ organisms including human (9606), mouse (10090), rat (10116), fly (7227), worm (6239), yeast (4932), and E. coli (511145).

faq.question: What confidence score should I use?
faq.answer: Use 400 for standard discovery, 700 for high-confidence analysis, and 900 for very stringent requirements. Lower scores include more false positives.

faq.question: Can I use this offline?
faq.answer: No. The skill requires internet access to query the STRING API at string-db.org. For offline use, download the complete database from the STRING download page.

faq.question: Is my query data sent elsewhere?
faq.answer: Queries are sent only to the official STRING database API. The caller_identity parameter helps with usage tracking but contains no user credentials.

faq.question: Why am I getting empty results?
faq.answer: Check that your species parameter matches your identifiers. Try mapping identifiers first with string_map_ids. Lower the confidence threshold if interactions exist but are below your threshold.

faq.question: How does this compare to Cytoscape?
faq.answer: STRING API provides programmatic access to interaction data and basic visualizations. Cytoscape offers advanced network analysis, customization, and integration with many plugins but requires desktop installation.
